items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
This flood alert has now been removed. 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Ivel in Hertfordshire and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: Levels are now below flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for drier conditions for the next 5 days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025). We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly for the next few days . We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but stable on the River Windrush following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in areas close to the river around Bourton on the Water and Newbridge. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025). We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Thames in the Abingdon area following recent  rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today.  We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025). We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid contact with flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Ray following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible overnight Wednesday 26.02.2025 into Thursday. The weather for the rest of today is likely to be mostly dry, with a settled few days ahead. We expect river levels to continue to rise and stay high for a couple of days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated Thursday morning, 27/02/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: River levels in the Lower Avon remain high due to high groundwater and the recent rainfall.  A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 01/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are rising steadily in response to recent rainfall. This information is correct as of 17:00 on Thursday 27 February.
The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 0.5 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the roads water may be deeper in places. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 28/02/2025.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are high but steady. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers, particularly around Longford. Property flooding is not expected. 

The next few days are expected to remain mostly dry, with no significant rainfall forecast. 

We are continuing to monitor river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Friday 28th February, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels rose on the River Dikler following recent heavy rainfall but levels but are now falling . Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today especially in areas close to the river near Bourton on the Water. We expect river levels to remain high over the next couple of days. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025).  We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Tove in Northamptonshire
items.message: River levels remain high after recent rainfall. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Tove between Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook and the Stoke Bruerne Marina. Move cars out of this flood risk area. Drier conditions are forecast for the rest of the week. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 28/02/2025.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels remain high after recent rainfall. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester may also be affected.  Drier conditions are forecast for the rest of the week. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 28/02/2025.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message: River levels are high but dropping at the Stinsford river gauge on the Lower Frome. Flooding is forecast to affect low lying areas near to the River Frome in the Dorchester, West Stafford, Bockhampton, Lewell, Tincleton, Pallington, Waddock, Moreton, Wool, East Stoke, Holmebridge, Stoborough, Stoborough Green, Wareham, Redcliffe, Ridge and Swineham areas. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 01/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches
River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but  have started to fall very slowly at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10am on Friday 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: River levels remain high after recent rainfall. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton.  Drier conditions are forecast for the rest of the week. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 28/02/2025.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
Flooding is affecting the road from Langport to Muchelney as the drain level exceeds 7.3m. For current water levels use https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels/target-area/112WAFYPM .
The road from Muchelney to Long Load is affected if it rises above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
We pump at Huish Episcopi pumping station when river levels allow. This looks likely to happen over the next few days if they remain dry. 
Staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please take care and refer to @TravelSomerset for information on road closures.
This message will be updated by 11am on 28/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are now falling on the Bear Brook in Aylesbury following yesterday's heavy rainfall. However,  the flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, especially in the Aylesbury area. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025). We expect levels to continue falling throughout the day, We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels have peaked and are slowly falling but remain high. The risk of flooding remains today 27/02/2025 and tomorrow 28/02/2025.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Largely dry weather conditions are forecast for the next few days so this flood alert is likely to be removed on Saturday 01/03/2025 but we will continue to closely monitor the situation.
This message will be updated by 3.00 PM on 28/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: East Somerset Rivers

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
Despite a spell of drier weather and generally falling river levels, this Flood Alert remains in force for the lower end of the Brue catchment, where significant volumes of floodwater remain on the low-lying levels and moors.
We are pumping and managing water levels where we can and continuing to monitor the situation.
Take care, check for local road closures and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated (or removed) by 4 pm on the 28/02/2025.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers in Hellingly and Alfriston are a little higher than normal, but falling, following Wednesday's rain. No rain is forecast for the next five days. The rivers will continue to fall. Minimal flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads will continue to ease. The river should return nearer to normal by Friday in Hellingly, and the weekend in Alfriston. Some roads may still be affected by flooding, please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if new instances of property flooding becomes possible.

items.description: Western Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is high in Fittleworth, and higher than normal near Selham. No rain is forecast for the next five days. River levels will fall. Flood impacts affecting gardens, fields, and roads will slowly ease over the coming days. River levels should return nearer to normal by the weekend near Selham, but not until next week near Fittleworth. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels should be near to normal by Friday. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if new instances of property flooding becomes possible.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Clyst and its tributaries has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message: River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 27/02/2025. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Observed peaks:- Upper Pound, Tewkesbury 2.99m overnight Monday 24/02/2025 and Mythe 2.88 overnight Tuesday 25/02/2025. No further rainfall is forecast during the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high, but slowly fall over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

Some roads may still be affected by flooding, please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 02:15 on 28/02/25, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 220 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 28/02/25, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon, 27/02/25, at 2.00pm, and is forecast to reach between 5.02 and 5.16 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, at 02:15 am and is forecast to reach between 4.84 and 4.98 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks again and flood low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected at Hampton this afternoon, 27/02/25, at 2.00pm, and is forecast to reach between 5.07 and 5.21 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, at 02:15 am and is forecast to reach between 4.88 and 5.02 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks again and flood low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Crane

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
The tide levels have now reduced on the River Crane, and river levels are starting to slowly reduce. High tides may require further flood alerts for this area later this week. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 

Standing water and debris may still remain. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Nadder and tributaries
Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: Groundwater levels are being kept high from previous heavy rainfall this week. They are very slowly starting to drop. We are expecting some further rainfall coming through on Wednesday. This may keep the groundwater levels high. Flooding of fields and roads is possible. Areas most at risk include: the Iwerne and the Pimperne Brook areas. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message: River levels in the River Bourne remain high due to the high groundwater and the recent rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected at the moment. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor your local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 01/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Hampshire Avon and tributaries
River Wylye and tributaries
River Piddle and tributaries
items.message: River levels continue to be high at Briantspuddle river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the Piddle and tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. There is no rainfall predicted for the next 4 to 5 days. We continue to monitor river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 01/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025).  We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Loddon at the Thames confluence at Twyford, as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible, or is expected adjacent to the river, especially in the Loddon Drive area of Wargrave, with flooding of roads affecting access to properties. Little or no further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling along most of the Upper Kennet. However flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, particularly in areas close to the River Dun near Hungerford where river levels are high but stable. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025).  We expect river levels to remain high in the Hungerford area for the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the Winterbourne Stream in Bagnor and the River Lambourn in Newbury. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue and we expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. The weather forecast is for a dry day today (27/02/2025).  We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Friday morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome from East Stoke to Wareham
Middle Hampshire Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message: River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon due to the rainfall yesterday (Wednesday 26th February) and the high groundwater levels.  Areas most at risk include areas in Britford, Charlton All Saints, Downton and Fordingbridge in close proximity to the River Avon. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and re-issue this warning if necessary.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. This message will be updated by 4pm on the 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible,  especially in the Shiplake and Wargrave areas. Little or no further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to continue to rise as water drains from further up the catchment. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible,  especially in the Marlow, Hurley, and Cookham areas. Little or no further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to continue to rise as water drains from further up the catchment. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: River Thames from Shepperton to Molesey

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames from Shepperton to Molesey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible for the next few days. Little or no further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to continue to remain high as water drains from further up the catchment. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lox
items.message: The River Lox is a little higher than normal, but falling. No rain is forecast for the next five days. The River Lox will continue to fall in all communities. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens will continue to ease along the length of the River Lox. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if new instances of property flooding becomes possible.

items.description: River Adur West Branch
items.message: The River Adur is a little higher than normal, but slowly falling, following Wednesday's rain. No rain is forecast for the next five days. The River Adur will continue to fall. Minimal flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads will continue to ease. The river should return nearer to normal by Friday. Some roads may still be affected by flooding. Please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if new instances of property flooding becomes possible.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon and tributaries
items.message: River levels are high and rising at the Salisbury Harnham Bridge gauge on the Middle Hampshire Avon due to the rainfall yesterday (Wednesday 26th February) and the high groundwater levels .  Areas most at risk include St Nicholas Road, the Close in Salisbury.  We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue this warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local.  Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and consider putting your flood plan into action.  Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  Residents are strongly urged to take action now.  Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.  This message will be updated by 4pm on the 28/02/25, or as the situation changes

items.description: Windle Brook and Hale, Mill and Addlestone Bournes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Windle Brook, Hale Bourne, Mill Bourne, Addlestone Bourne

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on The Addlestone Bourne, as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today. Little or no further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 28/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Arun
items.message: The River Arun is higher than normal and currently slowly rising, near Billingshurst and Pallingham Lock. Flood water will continue to affect gardens and fields near Pallingham Lock. Nearer Horsham, river levels are closer to normal, and are falling. Only minimal residual flood impacts are expected in Horsham, Broadbridge Heath and near Rudgwick. No rain is forecast for the next five days. The river will begin to fall near Pallingham Lock by 13:00 27/02/2025. In all other upstream communities, river levels will continue to fall. River levels should return nearer to normal by Friday near Horsham, but not until next week near Pallingham Lock. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to reduce flood risk in Horsham. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if new instances of property flooding becomes possible.

items.description: Lower Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high, but currently slowly falling at Pulborough. Water will continue to be in fields and near the A29, and gardens in Pulborough and Greatham. No rainfall is forecast for the next five days. The fall of river levels will slow in Pulborough on Thursday, as Wednesday's rain works through the community. It could be possible for river levels to rise slightly on Thursday, but will be falling again by Friday. River levels should return nearer to normal in Pulborough next week. Despite tide levels rising, peak water levels in Amberley and Arundel are not expected to be significantly higher than recent days. Flood impacts are only expected to affect fields in Amberley and Arundel. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if new instances of property flooding becomes possible.

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
The Colne Brook is high, but levels are steady. 

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible. Property flooding is not expected. 

Areas most at risk include Colnbrook Village, Poyle, Albany Park, High Street, Mill Street, Fawsley Close and Myrtle Close. 

The next few days are expected to remain mostly dry, with no significant rainfall forecast.  

We are continuing to monitor river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Friday 28th February, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels are remaining high due to previous rainfall. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. We are expecting some further rainfall coming on Wednesday (26th). This may keep the levels high. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels remain high after recent rainfall. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are those around the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield. Drier conditions are forecast for the rest of the week and will allow river levels to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 28/02/2025.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are beginning to fall though remain above flood alerts levels. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. Drier conditions are forecast for the rest of the week. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 28/02/2025.

items.description: River Wissey in Norfolk
items.message: River levels remain above the Flood Alert threshold. Flooding remains possible. Areas most at risk are those around the River Wissey from Bradenham to Denver including Watton Brook.  Drier conditions are forecast for the rest of the week and will allow river levels to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 28/02/2025.

items.description: Bin Brook in Cambridgeshire
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for drier conditions for the next 5 days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.   Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley.  Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.  Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and rising slowly. In the last week, over a month’s rain (65mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. At Preston Candover, the level has risen by 17cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to rise over the next 2 weeks. It is possible that isolated properties in Old Alresford could experience internal ground floor flooding in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 5th March 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 5th March 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall. . Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bourn Brook in Cambridgeshire
items.message: Levels are now below flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for drier conditions for the next 5 days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Wye and The Hughenden Stream
Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hursley are high and rising slowly. During the last week, nearly a month’s rain (56mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. During this time, the level at Hursley has risen by 16cm. Most of the village are now expected to be experiencing cellar flooding and sewerage system impacts. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to rise over the next week. Internal ground floor flooding is possible in the next 7 days. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: In the villages surrounding Andover, groundwater levels are high and relatively stable. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (32mm) has been recorded at Andover. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw and Hatherden, and is possible in Penton Grafton. Groundwater is flooding the main road into Penton Grafton and is emerging into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton. Impacts to the sewerage systems in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw are ongoing. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). If the heavier rain in the forecast affects the area, then groundwater levels will rise and cellar flooding in Kimpton and surface water flood risk in Thruxton could occur in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high and rising slowly. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (40mm) has been recorded at Overton. During this time, the level at Oakley has risen by 13cm. In Deane, cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising well into March in response to the rain already recorded this week. In early-March, it is possible that the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) will need to be closed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period and sensitive to further sustained periods of rainfall.  Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 04/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Wylye from Brixton Deverill to Warminster
Lower Wylye from Warminster to Wilton
River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message:
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram, due to persistent rainfall in December and January, leading to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn.

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern.

Rainfall is forecast throughout today, but is expected to clear later this afternoon. The forecast is then more settled for the rest of the week.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation. 

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 5th March 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high. During the last week, almost a month’s rain (45mm) has been recorded at Broughton. At Lopcombe, the level has fallen by 1.12m. At West Tytherley, the level has risen by 18cm. Minor flooding to land, gardens and the sewerage system is possible. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels at Lopcombe are expected to begin rising again in the next few days, in response to rain recorded in the last week. Ongoing flooding impacts will increase and cellar flooding in Nether Wallop may occur. At West Tytherley, the level is expected to continue rising slowly for another week. It is possible that flooding to cellars, land and roads could occur in the village in the next few days. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message: Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Gunner, Winterbourne Dauntsey, Winterbourne Earls and Laverstock . The groundwater level at the Clarendon borehole continue to rise. We are expecting some further rainfall on Wednesday (26th). We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 03/03/2025.

items.description: Lower Wylye at Wilton Town
